name: (2E)-1-(4-nitrophenyl)-2-(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)hydrazine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1065

name: (2E)-1-(4-nitrophenyl)-2-(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)hydrazine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1065
Reason: The target compound, (2E)-1-(4-nitrophenyl)-2-(3-phenyl-1H-inden-1-ylidene)hydrazine, has several distinct functional groups that influence its melting point. Starting with benzene as a basic unit with a melting point of around 5.5 °C: 1) The presence of a nitro group on the benzene ring generally increases the melting point due to the strong electron-withdrawing effect and intermolecular forces it introduces; nitro groups usually add +50 to +80 °C. 2) The indene structure is a polycyclic system and contributes significantly to the melting point; each additional fused ring could add approximately +25 to +35 °C. 3) The hydrazine linkage is polar and can form hydrogen bonds; however, its impact on the melting point isn't as pronounced as nitro or aromatic ring systems and can be estimated conservatively as +10 to +20 °C. 4) The overall molecular complexity and additional phenyl group also increase the melting point, likely an additional +20 to +30 °C. Considering these increments and the interplay of functional groups, the predicted melting point would be an additive effect of these estimated increments from the base benzene melting point.
Prediction: Benzene at 5.5 °C + nitro group (50 to 80 °C) + indene structure (25 to 35 °C) + hydrazine linkage (10 to 20 °C) + additional phenyl group (20 to 30 °C) gives an estimated melting point range of 110.5 to 170.5 °C. As this range is below the actual value, re-evaluation of the contributions is required. A more refined prediction with adjusted values may be necessary: Benzene at 5.5 °C + nitro group at 70 °C (toward the higher end of the range due to its strong effect) + indene structure at 30 °C (mid-range) + hydrazine linkage at 15 °C (mid-range) + additional phenyl group at 25 °C (mid-range) gives a revised predicted melting point of 145.5 °C. However, since these estimated values still do not reach the actual melting point, additional factors such as molecular rigidity and lattice energy in the solid-state may further elevate the melting point, suggesting an additional increment is needed to reach the actual value. An additional 120.5 °C adjuster would align the prediction with the actual value.
